For a President who talks about "America First," his budget puts Americans last.  During the campaign, Donald Trump promised to create good-paying jobs, invest in our infrastructure, and ensure that all Americans have the opportunity to thrive in the new economy. I have advocated for all those things myselfâ€”they are bipartisan priorities. Yet, President Trumpâ€™s budget makes no mention of jobs, infrastructure investment, or expanding economic opportunity for all Americans.  Trump's budget makes all the wrong trade-offs. Cutting investments in research and development that advance lifesaving medicines and spur untold economic innovation and job creation is beyond shortsighted. It is destructive to America. To pay for a wall that no one actually wants, Trump is gutting the Coast Guard and the airport security funding that protect our seas and skies. To build up a military to fight wars, Trump guts the State Departmentâ€™s capacity to avoid wars through diplomacy and directly puts our troops livesâ€™ at increased risk. To give massive tax cuts to millionaires and billionaires, Trump cuts entrepreneurship, rural investment, and job-training programs that support middle-class workers and small business owners. Itâ€™s all the wrong trade-offs.  Instead, Iâ€™d invest in America: in our people, in our schools, and in our infrastructure, to reignite the American Dream and spur our future prosperity as a nation. Trump's budget will prevent Americans from attaining economic opportunity and security, and Americans deserve a plan that helps all of us succeed in the new economy and prepares our country to win the 21st century.

What we need is a comprehensive, integrated political-military strategy to ensure the peace after our military actions are complete. So far we've heard nothing but silence from President Trump, either now or during is campaign, on what that strategy should be â€” silence, when over 8,000 Americans are still deployed there in the longest war in American history.   Dropping bombs on terrorists is the easy part. Ensuring the success of Afghan politics, so Afghanistan can protect its own people from terrorism, is much harder. But it is the only thing that will actually win the war and bring our troops home.

We need the American people to speak out now more than ever.

Massachusetts led the nation in affordable health care, and we did it in a bipartisan fashion -- with a Republican Governor and a Democratic legislature. The President asserted earlier this month that Qatar, a small nation in the Persian Gulf, was a sponsor of terrorism. A week later, he sold them $12 billion worth of weapons.  This Administrationâ€™s Middle East policy is an incoherent jumble of confusion and mixed messages. Qatar hosts one of the largest US military bases in the world, the Al Udeid Air Force Base, where over 12,000 Americans are stationed. Though Qatar has a mixed record on individual freedoms and the U.S. and Qatar have had disagreements in the past, it is an important, strategic base used to launch strikes against ISIS and other terrorists in the region. The Presidentâ€™s words have inflamed the crisis between Saudi Arabia and Qatar and stoked sectarian tensions. This is yet another concerning example of the Presidentâ€™s reckless, amateurish foreign policy.

Two years ago today, I stood on the steps of the Supreme Court when the decision that affirmed the right of same-sex couples to marry was handed down.  Marriage equality is personal for me.   Last week, I proposed to my girlfriend of two years, and she said yes! I'm going to be marrying the person I love. But until this day two years ago, my brother wasn't afforded the freedom to do the same in many states across America.  That SCOTUS decision was an important step towards equal rights for our LGBTQ brothers and sisters. Yet they still confront discrimination in the workplace and other barriers to equality depending on where they live.  Our Founding Fathers imbued our nation with freedom and equality, but these values require relentless leadership to maintain and expand. Despite all our progress, including this moment two years ago, we still have a long way to go. I will continue to fight for freedom and equality every day.

Congressional politics should never interfere with our ability to provide for our national defense. But with the Littoral Combat Ship, we are forcing on the Navy a ship that they do not want, a ship that they do not need, and a ship that they did not request.   Thatâ€™s why I submitted an amendment to the Department of Defense budget that would decrease LCS funding and reallocate it towards other needs that our commanders are requesting for our troops deployed across the globe.

For the United States to go to declare war, Congress must pass an Authorization for the Use of Military Force (AUMF). The same 60 word AUMF that was hastily written after September 11, 2001, has been used to justify at least 37 distinct military operations in 14 countries.   Yesterday, I called for Congress to debate the AUMF anew. We must have a robust, open, and substantive debate, because by failing to do so, we as a Congress are failing in our most solemn constitutional responsibility - that of declaring war and weighing the decision to send young American men and women into harmâ€™s way.

I'm calling on Congress to fulfill America's promise to the Afghans who support our troops in the fight against terrorism. They put their lives at risk and their families in danger by serving as interpreters alongside US forces, and we owe it to them to help resettle safely in the United States.

Anthony is a student from Hamilton who became interested in politics when he did a school project on President Obama. And I meant what I said: I hope that you'll stay passionate about getting involved in your community, and if I'm still in office when you're old enough to run for Congress, I hope you will run against me!

On Sunday, the Iraqi Prime Minister arrived in Mosul to formally declare victory, announcing the city had been recaptured from ISIS control. After nearly nine months of battling against ISIS, Iraqâ€™s armed forces have achieved a significant victory in the war on terror. While this is certainly great news, we have a long road ahead in stabilizing and rebuilding Mosul, and helping the millions displaced return home.    On behalf of the entire Congressional Iraq Caucus, Rep. Adam Kinzinger and I want to extend our congratulations and sincere gratitude to Iraqâ€™s military, our coalition allied forces, and the Iraqi people on this triumph. This hard-fought campaign must continue as we enter the next phase in our strategy to defeat ISIS.  Advising and assisting Iraqis in maintaining a secure Mosul is how we can best work together to ensure a stronger and stabilized Iraq, and prevent the re-emergence of a successor to ISIS.

EBSCO Information Services is a company headquartered in my district that has struggled to hire employees for good-paying jobs in technology because there aren't enough workers that have the skills they're looking for, and I've heard from many other employers and employees who are facing the same problem. The technology sector of the economy has grown at a torrid pace in recent years, but companies are struggling to hire the workers they need. Not enough Americans have the skills to succeed in today's digital economy.  I joined Radio Boston to talk about the CHANCE in Tech Act, a bipartisan bill I introduced to address this problem and prepare our workforce for the future of work.

I remain concerned about the lack of a clear plan or strategy in Syria. As the Syrian opposition, supported by American and allied forces, fights to defeat the Islamic State on the battlefield, we are being confronted by the question of what comes next. I submitted legislation requiring the Departments of Defense and State to prepare for Congress and for the American people a comprehensive military and political strategy for US policy in Syria.  We owe it to the young men and women who we ask to risk their lives in Syria today to tell them what the end goal is and why it is worth the risks that they take every single day.

Last week, I led an effort to clarify Spirit of America's legal status and the interactions it can have with the Department of Defense â€“ at no cost to the government â€“ that passed with bipartisan support.  Spirit of America Worldwide is an organization that supports American troops and humanitarian missions abroad. Their work is vital to stabilizing dangerous places around the world where US forces are operating. I'm grateful to my colleagues on both sides of the aisle who supported this legislation, which removes bureaucratic red tape by granting Spirit of America a Congressional charter.

The conditions described in this Boston Globe article are atrocious. Our veterans deserve the best health care in the world. Period. As a veteran, improving care at the VA is one of my top priorities. Thatâ€™s why I committed to continuing to get my own health care at the VA. I applaud Secretary Shulkinâ€™s decision to take action, but it never should have gotten to this point. I will continue to work with  my colleagues in Congress, as well as Secretary Shulkin, to ensure our veterans get the care they deserve.

The Senate health care plan was a terrible bill that had very little to do with health care, other than taking millions of Americans off of health care. This was all about a tax cut for the rich and shifting the tax burden to the middle class. We risked a lot of Americans getting hurt.   We should be focused on working together, both Democrats and Republicans, to improve health care - like we did in Massachusetts. I have always said that Obamacare isn't perfect, but repealing the law and leaving millions without coverage is not the answer. It's time to focus on finding bipartisan solutions to actually fix the law. I stand ready, as always, to work with my colleagues in both chambers on both sides of the aisle to do just that.

One thing that I know we all share is a belief that free and fair elections are the cornerstone of our democracy. Foreign interference in our elections undermines the public trust and casts doubt on the legitimacy of our government. That is why I am offering this amendment, which will ensure adequate funding for Special Counsel Robert Mueller, appointed by the Department of Justice, so that he can perform a thorough and nonpartisan investigation of Russiaâ€™s campaign to affect the 2016 U.S. presidential election and any individuals in the United States that may have colluded in those efforts.
I'm hosting a forum this morning to talk about how we can put Americans back to work in the new economy. Please tune in live:

Iâ€™m in between sessions of the Budget Committee, where weâ€™re marking up the Republican budget. At a time when we should be talking how to prepare for the new economy, the Republican budget proposal guts what people need. Just this morning, I held a forum on the future of work. We brought in experts to talk about how the economy is changing and how America needs to adapt. The irony is that this budget does the exact opposite. It takes away dollars from education. It takes away dollars from the programs we rely on for retirement, for switching between jobs, and for healthcare.
This evening, I offered an amendment to the federal budget that would ensure adequate funding for Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russia's attack on our 2016 election.

Capt. Jennifer Harris, of Swampscott, was a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy and a Sea Knight helicopter pilot. Her aircraft was shot down by insurgents in Iraq on February 7, 2007, as she was transporting blood supplies to troops in need.  I have never seen more people of Swampscott lining the roads than on the frigid day in the middle of a New England winter when we marched for her funeral. The town honored her beautifully on that day, but with a memorial in Washington, her friends and family will have a place to honor her sacrifice for the rest of their lives.  On Friday, President Trump signed the Global War on Terrorism War Memorial Act into law after it unanimously passed both the House and the Senate. This is a major milestone in a journey my office started more than a year ago as a bipartisan effort to create a memorial honoring those who have served on active duty in the longest war in American history.

The Democratic National Security Task Force is stepping into the Trump Administrationâ€™s leadership vacuum and has convened experts and devised strategy to provide a smarter, stronger approach to North Koreaâ€™s unacceptable behavior. As a Co-Chair of the task force, I am proud to be joined by 67 other Democrats who are ready to provide steady leadership while President Trumpâ€™s bluster risks blundering us into a nuclear war.  The President is clearly not on the same page as his own Secretary of Defense and Secretary of State. This makes his military threats not credible; it leads our allies to view us as untrustworthy, right when they need us most; and by ratcheting up tensions, he is closing down diplomatic options when they are most critical.  Our letter outlines a strategy for North Korea that would impose and effectively enforce more sanctions; prepare for tough negotiations without preconditions; strengthen our alliances with South Korea, Japan, and regional partners; and nominate qualified individuals to critical, unfilled positions at the Department of State and the Department of Defense.

Addressing the City Awake "Our Convention" yesterday - encourage rising leaders to answer the call to serve. "So, my request of all of you is not just to be willing to stand up. "We are a nation of immigrants â€“ it is core to who we always have been as the United States of America. Generations of immigrants have been our friends and neighbors, fought to protect us overseas, and helped build our economy here at home... As your representative in Congress, I have been a vocal advocate for serious immigration reform. It is a place where we ought to set aside our party differences and come together as Americans â€“ Democrats and Republicans, the Congress and the White House â€“ to make us both a more secure and a more welcoming country.Until my colleagues in congressional leadership can agree to have that discussion and address this problem, however, we need to take commonsense steps to keep our communities safe and prosperous as we work towards broader reform. This is why I will be voting yes on Salem's Question 1, the proposed "Sanctuary for Peace" ordinance...Beyond the economic benefits, and the statistics that show crime is lower in sanctuary cities, we owe it to our friends and neighbors who are already a part of our communities to feel safe and welcomed. In these politically divisive times, let us choose love over hate, safety over fear, and compassion over ridicule. We must continue to work to reform our immigration system, but let us do so thoughtfully while ensuring the safety of our communities. I urge full support for the Sanctuary for Peace Ordinance, because I know that Salem is â€“ and should remain â€“ a safe and welcoming city."

Of course the opioid epidemic is a public health emergency. Now that the Administration has made this declaration, it's time for the president to actually act. Republicans cannot have the best of both worlds. We cannot keep having conversations about gutting the ACA while simultaneously talking about the opioid epidemic. And we cannot declare a public health emergency without actually allocating resources to help combat it. Only 1 in 10 people with an opioid addiction is receiving the treatment he or she needs, and this is largely because of a lack of insurance. Now more than ever, we must rise above politics - peoples lives are literally on the line. My district, like so many others, has been impacted by opioid addiction. This epidemic has touched all of us personally in some way and it's time to act. I will continue to focus my efforts on ensuring more Americans have health care coverage and access to treatment. I invite my colleagues to stop trying to drive premiums up and coverage down so we can actually focus on the task at hand - making our communities healthier and safer.
